tossups.question: One painting by this artist depicts a boy carrying a melon talking to an old woman who is cooking eggs. This artist may have included himself in the bottom right of a painting showing an array of lances in the right background as a Dutch soldier extends a key. Francis Bacon painted a series of variants of a portrait by this artist showing the title figure in a rich red cloak and hat. In addition to a portrait of (*) Pope Innocent X, this artist depicted two paintings by Paul Rubens hanging in the background in a work set in Philip IV's palace. This artist painted himself looking at the viewer in a work showing servants attending to the Infanta Margarita. For 10 points, name this Spanish artist of Las Meninas.

During the rule of this king, Oliver St. John [Sinjin] played an important role in the impeachment of Thomas Wentworth. After adding a new Book of Common Prayer, this king fought the Bishop's War against the subsequent rebellion. That event was partially caused by this king's appointment of a new Archbishop of Canterbury, William Laud. This king financed his kingdom using "ship money" and (*) "popish soap" while  he refused to call Parliament for 11 years during "personal rule." This king lost the Battle of Marston Moor, where his cavalry was led by Prince Rupert. This king was captured at the Battle of Naseby by the New Model Army. For 10 points, name this Stuart king who was executed by Oliver Cromwell after the English Civil War.
tossups.answer: Charles I of England [prompt on Charles]

tossups.question: This woman's father built a statue of Aidos, or modesty, at the site where this woman indicated to him that she would marry her husband. This woman gave birth to Italus with a man who killed this woman's husband using a lance with a stingray spine. Eumachus and Philoetius slew attempted suitors of this woman. Antinous and (*) Eurymachus competed to marry this woman, whose bed was made from a living olive tree and so was unmoveable. This woman instructed suitors to shoot an arrow through a dozen axes. This woman pretended to weave a burial shroud for Laertes which she tore down every night to keep suitors at bay. For 10 points, name this mother of Telemachus and wife of Odysseus.

The dislocation of small cations in these materials can create anomalies named for Frenkel. In these materials, the set of points in the reciprocal space that are closer to the origin than any other reciprocal point are known as the first Brillouin zone. These materials are deposited in films in epitaxy. These materials often grow around a "seed," which acts as a nucleation site. The relation (*) n times lambda equals 2d sin theta holds when these materials act as a diffraction grating for incident x-rays, according to Bragg's law. These materials are contrasted with amorphous solids, since they have periodic patterns of unit cells. For 10 points, name these materials that consist of a regular repeating arrangement of atoms.
tossups.answer: crystal lattice [accept crystalline solids; accept seed crystal; prompt on lattices; prompt on network solids]
tossups.answer_formatted: crystal lattice [accept crystalline solids; accept seed crystal; prompt on lattices; prompt on network solids]

tossups.question: In a work by this author, a "canvas-covered wagon" is thought to leave a baby before crossing Coton Mais's ferry. In that work by this author, a character was found "lying in the shadow of the big stone pillar" as a baby at Valmondé. One story by this author describes a woman taking her baby from Zandrine before walking out into a field of reeds. In that story by this author, a man burns his wife's possessions but discovers that his mother was a (*) slave. This author wrote of Louise learning that Brently Mallard is dead before he reappears alive in one short story. Another short story by this author of "The Story of an Hour" describes Armand and Desirée's reactions to the dark skin of Desirée's baby. For 10 points, name this Louisianan author of The Awakening

One conflict in this state began when Franklin Coleman was not arrested for murdering Charles Dow in a land dispute. Charles Hamilton carried out the Marais des Cygnes massacre in this state. This state's constitution, the Wyandotte Constitution, was accepted after the Leavenworth and Lecompton Constitutions were rejected. Rifles used in this state became known as (*) "Beecher's Bibles." Charles Sumner was caned for delivering a speech called "The Crime against [this state]." John Brown attacked settlers in the Pottawatomie Massacre in retaliation for the sack of Lawrence in this state. Guerrillas that fought Missouri's bushwhackers gave this state the nickname of "jayhawk." For 10 points, name this state which was "bleeding" in the lead-up to the Civil War.

In humans, part of this organ develops from the first pharyngeal pouch. This organ's stereocilia are arranged by increasing height. Presbycusis is the natural loss of function of this organ. This organ's utricle and saccule contain small calcium carbonate particles and are located behind the oval window. The movement of fluid along three planes allows this organ to sense angular (*) acceleration in its semicircular canals. In this organ, the bending of hair cells changes the frequency of action potentials in the organ of Corti. This organ's tympanic membrane is connected to three small bones, the malleus, incus, and stapes, which are responsible for transmitting vibrations to the cochlea. For 10 points, name this organ that is responsible for balance and hearing.
tossups.answer: ear [accept inner ear; anti-prompt on cochlea or organ of Corti before mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: ear [accept inner ear; anti-prompt on cochlea or organ of Corti before mentioned]

tossups.question: August Wenzinger is most famous for editing an authoritative edition of six works by this composer. This composer, many of whose works are performed from transcriptions by Ferruccio Busoni, wrote a concerto whose second movement only consists of a Phrygian half-cadence, around which the soloist is to improvise. This composer, who frequently collaborated with the librettist Picander, used a (*) Lutheran hymn written by Philipp Nicolai for his "Wachet Auf." A piece by this composer was adapted into Charles Gounod's Ave Maria. A revival of this composer's music began with Felix Mendelssohn's performance of their St. Matthew Passion. For 10 points, name this Baroque composer of The Well-Tempered Clavier and several Brandenburg Concertos.
tossups.answer: Johann Sebastian Bach [or J. S. Bach; prompt on Bach or Johann Bach]
tossups.answer_formatted: Johann Sebastian Bach [or J. S. Bach; prompt on Bach or Johann Bach]

tossups.question: A speaker of a poem in this work contrasts the "long dream of life" with the "short dream of a game" and ends by saying "wake up." An audio track within this work starts with vinyl static before a person starts running on stone and coughing; that track is called "11" and was composed by C418. An update to this game added new features like axolotls. An anonymous (*) astrophysicist wrote a report exonerating high incidences of blaze rod and ender pearl drops by a speedrunner of this game named Dream. This game features a playable character named Steve and has a final goal of defeating the Ender Dragon. For 10 points, name this video game with "Java" and "Bedrock" editions developed by Mojang.

The narrator of one poem by this author "armed [himself] against Justice" and compares life to a "feast where all hearts opened, and all wines flowed." The speaker of a poem by this author was "indifferent" to the "bearer of Flemish wheat or English cottons." A section of a poem by this author mentions how the narrator assigned different colors to the vowels. The title object of one poem by this author "no longer felt myself guided by haulers" as it moved down (*) "impassive Rivers." One section of a poem by this author contains two Delirium sections, the first of which is an allegory for his relationship with Paul Verlaine. For 10 points, name this French symbolist poet who wrote A Season in Hell and "The Drunken Boat."

This architect designed a memorial with a stainless steel tapestry of the French coast next to 8 stone columns. This architect asked Cooseje van Bruggen and Claus Oldenburg to build a giant binocular sculpture as part of his Chiat/Day building. This architect of the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial worked with Vlado Milunic to design a building he initially called (*) "Fred and Ginger." This architect designed a pedestrian bridge that connects Millenium Park in Chicago with the rest of Grant Park. This architect clad a building by the Nervión River in thin titanium plates. This architect of the Dancing House also designed Seattle's Museum of Pop Culture and the Walt Disney Concert Hall. For 10 points, name this Canadian architect who created the Bilbao Guggenheim.

Swimming feats were twice performed by this politician to demonstrate his health before he announced major plans. In one text explaining this politician's views, he pointed out that "a revolution is not a dinner party." This politician developed the concept of the mass line while his administration developed struggle sessions. Schemes of this politician were criticized in the quote (*) "I don't care if the cat is black or white, so long as it catches mice." This politician advocated expanding the proletariat to include peasants as a cornerstone of his namesake ideology. The Little Red Book was written by this thinker, who also led the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution. For 10 points, name this communist who established the People's Republic of China.

An author from this country recalls being approached by Janet Suzman to act in a production of Othello in one essay. That author, John Kani, collaborated on a play with another author from this country, in which the title character adopts the pass book and identity of Robert Zwelinzima. At the end of another play by an author from this country, the protagonist writes an English essay about ballroom dancing as a (*) "world without collisions." A character named Morris poses as his brother Zachariah to impress a woman named Ethel Lange in a play set in this country. A servant named Sam is spit on in the face by a character who claims that "you can't fly kites on rainy days" named Hally in a play from this country. For 10 points, name this home country of  Athol Fugard.
tossups.answer: South Africa [the first essay is "Apartheid and Othello"]
tossups.answer_formatted: South Africa [the first essay is "Apartheid and Othello"]

tossups.question: The propagator of one type of these systems is given by the Mehler kernel. That system is improved on by the Morse potential. The eigenvalues of the wavefunctions of those systems are described by the Hermite polynomials. When one type of these systems return to equilibrium as quickly as possible, they have a Q factor of one-half and are (*) critically damped. One type of these systems have energy levels at 2n plus 1 times h-bar times angular frequency over two. The potential energy of one type of these systems equals one-half times k times displacement squared. For 10 points, name these systems with a restoring force proportional to the displacement, an example of which is a spring.
tossups.answer: harmonic oscillators [accept simple harmonic oscillators or quantum harmonic oscillators or SHO or QHO; prompt on oscillator]
tossups.answer_formatted: harmonic oscillators [accept simple harmonic oscillators or quantum harmonic oscillators or SHO or QHO; prompt on oscillator]

tossups.question: One candidate for office in this city was accused of not living there because of the presence of salmon in his supposed refrigerator. Candidates for one election in this city guessed wildly inaccurate numbers when asked to name the $900,000 median home sales price in one region of this city. Fernando Mateo lost one primary election in this city to the founder of Guardian Angels, (*) Curtis Sliwa. The campaign apparatus of Dianne Morales fell apart in one election in this city. Kathryn Garcia and Maya Wiley both lost a primary election in this city. This city re-implemented ranked choice voting for its 2020 Democratic primary, which featured Andrew Yang. For 10 points, name this city where Eric Adams is the Democratic candidate to replace Bill de Blasio.
tossups.answer: New York City [accept NYC or the Big Apple]

tossups.question: The proverb "money does not stink" is attributed to this emperor's reinstatement of the tax on urine. While dying of severe diarrhea, this emperor's last words were "I think I'm becoming a god." The general Mucianus helped this man win the Second Battle of Bedriacum. This emperor freed the slave Josephus, who had earlier chronicled the Siege of Yodfat. This man led the invasion of Galilee as part of his victory in the (*) Great Jewish revolt; 11 years later, this man's son had a namesake arch built for him. This man defeated Vitellius, ending the year of the four emperors. This man began construction of the Coliseum, which was completed by his son, Titus. For 10 points, name this emperor who founded the Flavian dynasty.

Two groups of figures in this religion are contrasted as being sweet and cool or violent and hot. This religion compares being possessed by a spirit to a horse being mounted. This religion identifies the ancestral spirits as Ginen. One deity in this religion is often depicted as an old man wearing rags who stands at a crossroad. Vévés drawn on the floor in this religion may represent figures such as (*) Maman Brigitte or her husband Baron Samedi. The supreme deity of this religion is known as Bondye. This religion's priests, who are known as either Oungan or Manbo, use Papa Legba to talk to spirits called Lwa [Loa]. For 10 points, name this syncretic religion practiced in Haiti known for its namesake dolls

A character in one novel by this author dreams about working in an open-plan office and goes on a trip to Norfolk after Rodney tells her about a "possible." Another novel by this author sees the protagonist defend a character when that character is accused of being a Nazi sympathizer after hosting Herr Ribbentrop at his house. One novel by this author is titled after a Judy Bridgewater song while another features the protagonist attempting to learn the art of (*) bantering to please his American employer Mr. Farraday. One novel by this author features Kathy, Ruth, and Tommy who are clones that are raised at Hailsham to become organ donors. For 10 points, name this author who wrote Never Let Me Go and who wrote about the butler Stevens in The Remains of the Day.

This man was accused of cherry-picking certain ethnic groups, Sicilians and "Hebrews," to support his claim that the children of immigrants were more similar to other Americans physically than to people in their homeland. George Hunt consulted for this man's work leading the Jesup North Pacific Expedition. This man developed a school termed "historical particularism," which he taught to students like Alfred (*) Kroeber. This man popularized a system using linguistics and archeology as two of its "four fields." The Central Eskimo was written after this man's study of native Inuit on Baffin Island. In one work, this man studies the Kwakiutl tribe and their gift-giving feast known as potlatch. For 10 points, name this author of The Mind of Primitive Man, a Columbia professor who taught Margaret Mead.

It's not height, but this quantity is measured by aneroid wafers. Thickness is proportional to the natural log of the ratio of two values of this quantity, according to the hypsometric equation. Forces caused by differences in this quantity are balanced against the Coriolis force in geostrophic currents. The gap between Hadley cells causes this quantity to be relatively (*) low in a belt along the equator. Changes in this quantity are related to density and little-g by the hydrostatic equation. Winds are caused by gradients in this quantity. Isobars join points with equal levels of this quantity. For 10 points, name this quantity that can be measured in millimeters of mercury or torrs.
tossups.answer: pressure [accept atmospheric pressure; accept pressure gradient]

bonuses.leadin: The Kepler problem concerns the behavior of a system with this number of objects orbiting in space. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this number. This is the maximum value of n such that the n-body system always has an exact solution.
The Kepler problem can be simplified because it undergoes motion due to the central type of this quantity. This quantity is measured in Newtons.
This quantity's vector, which is proportional to the LRL vector, is conserved in the Kepler problem. For Earth, this quantity is approximately 0.016.
answers: eccentricity [accept eccentricity vector; prompt on e]

bonuses.leadin: One character in this play asks Frank Lubey to draw up a horoscope for her missing son. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play in which a character named Larry goes missing after learning that his father Joe sold faulty airplane parts.
All My Sons is by this playwright who also wrote about Willy Loman in Death of a Salesman.
Mother Keller cherishes one of these objects that was erected in memory of the missing Larry Keller. At the beginning of All My Sons, this object is struck by lightning.

bonuses.leadin: This organization defeated many of its rivals in the Carnatic wars. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organization. One mutiny against this organization was caused by the supposed presence of animal grease in the cartridges of the Enfield rifle.
The Sepoy mutiny occured partially due to allegations that the grease contained parts of this animal. This animal is sacred to Hindus.
This policy was introduced by the British government following the Sepoy mutiny. Due to this policy, Hindu rulers could not adopt a successor, allowing the British to annex their land once they died.
answers: British East India Company [or BEIC; accept Honourable East India Company, English East India Company; prompt on East India Company]
answers_formatted: British East India Company [or BEIC; accept Honourable East India Company, English East India Company; prompt on East India Company]
acceptable: Honourable East India Company, English East India Company

bonuses.leadin: This woman posed for the painting The Madonna of Port Lligat. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist's wife who modelled for many of his paintings after separating from Paul Éluard. This woman was also painted in a painting titled "[a variation of her name] of the Spheres."
Gala was the wife of this artist, who painted The Madonna of Port Lligat. He is better known for painting The Persistence of Memory.
Dali depicted Gala likely disapproving of bullfighting in this painting. This painting depicts multiple images of the Venus de Milo in addition to a bullfighter.
answers: Gala Dalí [accept Galatea; accept Elena Ivanovna Diakonova; prompt on Dalí or Éluard]
answers_formatted: Gala Dalí [accept Galatea; accept Elena Ivanovna Diakonova; prompt on Dalí or Éluard]

bonuses.leadin: This woman held a banquet for women while her husband threw a banquet for the princes of Persia. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this queen who is dismissed on the advice of Memucan after refusing to display her beauty for King Ahasuerus.
This woman replaced Vashti as the wife of King Ahasuerus. This woman helped to save her cousin Mordecai from death by interceding with Ahasuerus.
This holiday celebrates the events of the Book of Esther, particularly Haman's plot to extinguish the Jews being foiled. This holiday is celebrated during the month of Adar.

bonuses.leadin: In 2021, Veritasium published a video exploring the "holes at the bottom of math." Answer the following about these "holes," for 10 points each:
parts: This man's first incompleteness theorem showed that for any mathematical system, there exists statements that cannot be proven true.

Godel's second incompleteness theorem showed that a system with this property cannot show it has this property. Systems with this property are not complete, according to Godel's first incompleteness theorem.

This computer scientist's halting problem showed that no algorithm can tell whether a program will halt or loop, thus showing how math is undecidable. This person's work cracking the enigma machine during World War II eventually led to the first computers.

bonuses.leadin: The protagonist of a novel convinces Ben Rogers to perform this task in exchange for his apple. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this task which Aunt Polly sends the protagonist out to do on a Saturday morning. That character instead trades items with other people in exchange for them performing this task.
This character, the protagonist of a Mark Twain novel, is told to whitewash the fence. This friend of Huckleberry Finn falls in love with a girl named Becky Thatcher.
Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn observe the murder of Dr. Robinson by this character after hiding in a graveyard. This character starves to death after being trapped in McDougal's Cave.

bonuses.leadin: The many fast days prescribed by this country's Orthodox Tewahedo Church led to the development of many vegan dishes, some of which are eaten with injera. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country in the Horn of Africa. The capital of this country is Addis Ababa.
This town in the Amhara region is a major pilgrimage site, along with Axum, for members of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church. It is notable for its eleven churches carved directly out of rock.

The Ethiopian Orthodox Church is doctrinally close to this country's church, although they have sometimes disagreed because of tensions between Ethiopia and this country. The capital of this country is Asmara.

bonuses.leadin: This person used a zinc sulfide screen in an experiment he conducted with Ernest Marsden. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this person that developed a namesake "counter" that clicks when it detects radioactive particles.
Geiger counters designed to detect these particles contain the gas boron trifluoride. This particle is produced alongside a positron and neutrino in beta-plus decay.

These devices are used instead of Geiger counters to detect ionizing radiation. High energy photons strike these devices and re-emit light, and they are connected to photomultiplier tubes to produce electric signals.
answers: scintillation counter [accept scintillators or scintillation detectors or scintillation cameras]

bonuses.leadin: This king retreated after being told by a potential assassin that there would be 299 more assassins coming to kill him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this king of Clusium, who retreated from a siege of Rome after the aforementioned assassin Mucius stuck his hand in a fire to prove his valor. Cloelia was taken hostage by the forces of this king.
Lars Porcena was ostensibly helping this man regain his control of Rome. This man, supposedly the son of an earlier king with a similar name, lost power after his son raped Lucretia.
Tarquin the Proud was overthrown by one man with this name. A descendent of that man with this name was legendarily asked "Et tu" by Julius Caesar.
answers: Lars Porsena [accept Lars Porsena or Pursenas]
Tarquin the Proud [accept Lucius Tarquinius Superbus; prompt on Tarquinius; do not accept "Lucius Tarquinius Priscus]
Brutus [accept Lucius Junius Brutus or Marcus Junius Brutus]
answers_formatted: Tarquin the Proud [accept Lucius Tarquinius Superbus; prompt on Tarquinius; do not accept "Lucius Tarquinius Priscus"]

bonuses.leadin: In this work, the author points to the ending of A Passage to India as an example of how the gulf between the West and the title region cannot be fully crossed. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work of postcolonial theory. This work analyzes the false, Eurocentric view of the East promulgated by Western scholars.
The second part of Said's Orientalism begins with a discussion of "Bouvard's vision of Europe regenerated by Asia," referencing one of this author's characters. This author also wrote Madame Bovary.

Said compares the orientalism of Flaubert's Salammbo to this author's novel Victory, in which Axel Heyst is attracted to the musician Alma. Said's The World, The Text, and The Critic includes a biographical examination of this author's work, including a novel partially set aboard the Patna.

bonuses.leadin: This programmer donated 50 Trillion Shiba Inu coins to a fund for COVID relief in India. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this programmer. He recently discussed his willingness to merge Dogecoin with the cryptocurrency Ethereum, which he first proposed.
Buterin also co-founded a magazine named for this cryptocurrency, which Ethereum was supposed to improve upon. This is the first decentralized cryptocurrency and also the one with the highest price.
Both Ethereum and Bitcoin depend on one of these structures. These structures are composed of records linked together using cryptographic hashes.

bonuses.leadin: This god once kidnapped the rain god Tlaloc's bride Xochiquetzal and married her. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this god who transformed into a jaguar to destroy the first creation after he was hit out of the sky. This god's name translates as "Smoking Mirror.
Tezcatlipoca's name alludes to a story in which he lost his foot and it was replaced with a mirror made of this substance. Consequently, Tezcatlipoca was considered a god of this substance.
Tezcatlipoca was worshiped by this Mesoamerican civilization primarily. These people also worshipped Quetzalcoatl, who may be a sibling of Tezcatlipoca.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about things that happened in 1979:
parts: In the "Winter of Discontent," one of these events, public sector workers refused to work. Teachers often participate in these events by walking out of schools.

This Tory politician became the United Kingdom's Prime Minister, ushering in new neoliberal programs of free trade and reduced public spending. This prime minister controversially abolished free milk for school children.

In 1979, Supreme Allied Commander of NATO Alexander Haig was nearly assassinated by this group. Earlier, this West German terrorist group had killed former Nazi Hanns Martin Schleyer during the "German Autumn."
answers: strike [accept labor strike or worker strike]
Red Army Faction [or RAF; or Baader-Meinhof Gang]

bonuses.leadin: In this ballet, one character puts an ear of corn to her ear in an attempt to obtain advice on whether she should marry; unfortunately, the corn remains silent. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Leo Delibes ballet, based on stories by E. T. A. Hoffmann. This ballet ends with the Burgomaster paying damages to a certain character, allowing Franz and Swanilda to enter into a happy marriage.

During the festivities in the first movement of Coppelia, the townspeople perform a Czardas, a dance from this country. Franz Liszt drew upon the Verbunkos dance from this home country of his for a set of nineteen Rhapsodies.
This Georgian-American choreographer completely rewrote the third act of Coppelia for a performance by the New York Ballet, which he co-founded with Lincoln Kirstein.

bonuses.leadin: This craft is generally used to make granny squares, which are created from the inside first. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this craft which uses a single hook and yarn. This craft uses single and double stitches, as well as chains.
Although crochet yarn can be made from cotton, llamas, or synthetic materials, crochet yarn is commonly made from the wool produced by shearing these animals.
This practice of crocheting stuffed toys, such as animals, dolls, or mini food items, originated in Japan.
answers: sheep [accept Ovis aries; accept ewe or ram or lamb; accept ovine]

bonuses.leadin: Proteins often absorb electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths of about 280 nanometers and 200 nanometers. For 10 points each:
parts: This largest amino acid is responsible for the majority of the absorption at 280 nanometers. Due to its size, this amino acid absorbs at a wavelength higher than tyrosine or phenylalanine.
The absorption at 200 nanometers is due to the presence of this type of bond. These bonds are formed between the A and P sites of the ribosome.
The peaks at 280 nanometers and 200 nanometers are measured in a type of spectroscopy named after ultraviolet light and this type of light. Humans see in this range of light.
answers: peptide bonds [prompt on covalent bonds or amide bonds]

bonuses.leadin: During a conflict in this country, the Poles of the Dabrowski legion defected from the command of the Vicomte de Rochambeau to the armies of Jean-Jacques Dessalines. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country. Toussaint L'Ouverture led a revolution in this Caribbean country against the French.
A history of the Haitian revolution by C. L. R. James is titled for Black equivalents of this political society. This club, opposed by the Girondins, was founded by Maximilien Robespierre.

Some Haitian revolutionaries later participated in a march on this city in the German Coast revolt. After his capture of this city, Benjamin Butler issued General Order No. 28, leading to him being nicknamed "The Beast."

bonuses.leadin: Isao Tomita's pioneering electronic music album Snowflakes are Dancing mainly contains material inspired by this composer. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French impressionist composer of Clair de Lune.
Several tracks off the album are drawn from this Debussy collection, which includes pieces titled for "Footprints in the Snow" and a "Maid with Flaxen Hair."
Tomita performed the album on one of these instruments, also used by Wendy Carlos in her album Switched-On Bach.

bonuses.leadin: One poet's interest in this language was sparked when he obtained the papers of Ernest Fenollosa. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this language. Despite not knowing this language, the Imagist poet Ezra Pound claimed to have "translated" The River Merchant's Wife, a poem written in this language by Li Bai.

In Cathay, Pound presented an extremely loose "translation" of the "Song of the Bowmen of Shu," which is contained in this Chinese poetry collection. One of the many "airs from the states" in this collection begins by juxtaposing images of "ospreys / on an islet in the river" and a "modest, retiring, virtuous young lady."
Pound drew from Fenollosa's papers for a study of this oldest genre of Japanese drama, which was partially developed by Zeami Motokiyo. It's not kyogen, but actors in this genre wear omote, or masks.
answers: Shijing [or Maoshi or Book of Songs or Book of Poetry or Book of Odes or Classic of Poetry; do NOT accept or prompt on "Shujing"]
answers_formatted: Shijing [or Maoshi or Book of Songs or Book of Poetry or Book of Odes or Classic of Poetry; do NOT accept or prompt on "Shujing"]
